# Morocco 2030 — A Cultural Guide to the FIFA World Cup

> A Slow Morocco project. Powered by Dancing with Lions.

Morocco 2030 is a cultural travel guide to the six Moroccan host cities for the 2030 FIFA World Cup. It covers what visitors need to know beyond the stadiums: city guides, food, language, transport, weather, and practical intelligence.

## Host Cities & Stadiums

- Casablanca — Grand Stade Hassan II (115,000 seats, new build, completion 2028)
- Marrakech — Marrakech Stadium (70,000 seats, expansion)
- Rabat — Prince Moulay Abdellah (68,700 seats, new build, completed 2025)
- Tangier — Ibn Batouta Stadium (75,600 seats, expansion)
- Fes — Fes Stadium (55,800 seats, expansion from 35,500)
- Agadir — Adrar Stadium (70,000 seats, expansion from 46,000)

## Key Facts

- The 2030 World Cup is co-hosted by Morocco, Portugal, and Spain
- First World Cup held across two continents (Africa and Europe)
- First World Cup in North Africa since football began
- Tournament dates: June–July 2030
- Currency: Moroccan Dirham (MAD), roughly 10 MAD = €1
- Languages: Darija (Moroccan Arabic), Tamazight, French, Spanish, English

## Transport (2030 Network)

- High-speed rail (Al Boraq) connects Tangier–Casablanca–Marrakech
- Fes to Marrakech: 3h 40m by train (currently 6h 30m)
- Domestic flights: 45 min between most city pairs
- Private drivers: €80–150 per day

## Moroccan Food

- Tagine — slow-cooked in conical clay pot
- Couscous — Friday lunch tradition, steamed semolina with seven vegetables
- Pastilla — pigeon/chicken in pastry with almonds, cinnamon, powdered sugar
- Harira — tomato, lentil, chickpea soup
- Mechoui — whole lamb slow-roasted in clay pit
- Mint tea — gunpowder green tea with fresh mint, poured from height

## Essential Darija Phrases

- Salam alaykum — Peace be upon you (hello)
- Shukran — Thank you
- Bslama — Goodbye
- La bas? — How are you?
- Bsh-hal? — How much?
- Dima Maghrib! — Always Morocco! (stadium chant)
